BasicDescription.Title: The Moral Maze
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Michael Buerk chairs a debate on the moral questions behind the week's news. Steven Rose, Claire Fox, Michael Gove and Melanie Phillips cross-examine witnesses.

BasicDescription.Title: Book Of The Week
BasicDescription.Synopsis: My Life As Me: Barry Humphries casts off his Dame Edna mantle to read from his hilarious autobiography. He describes how he met Salvador Dali and his wife. .

BasicDescription.Title: Any Questions?
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Jonathan Dimbleby chairs a topical discussion from Burford School in Oxfordshire. The panel includes Patricia Hewitt MP, Lord Jenkins and author Frederick Forsyth.

BasicDescription.Title: Letter From America
BasicDescription.Synopsis: By Alistair Cooke. Insight, anecdote and history from the doyen of commentators.

BasicDescription.Title: Midnight News
BasicDescription.Synopsis: The latest national and international news from BBC Radio 4.

BasicDescription.Title: Shipping Forecast
BasicDescription.Synopsis: The latest Shipping Forecast.

BasicDescription.Title: As BBC World Service
BasicDescription.Synopsis: BBC Radio 4 joins the BBC World Service for a selection of news and current affairs, arts and science programmes. BBC Radio 4 resumes at 5.35am.

BasicDescription.Title: Radio 4 Open Up
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Includes a News Summary, the latest Shipping and Inshore Waters forecasts, and Prayer For The Day.

BasicDescription.Title: News
BasicDescription.Synopsis: The latest national and international news from BBC Radio 4. Followed by Weather, a review of today's newspapers and Sports Desk.

BasicDescription.Title: Open Country
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Helen Mark uncovers meets the people and wildlife of the British countryside.

BasicDescription.Title: Farming Today This Week
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Miriam O'Reilly presents this week's countryside and agricultural news, with comment from Radio 4's experts.

BasicDescription.Title: Today
BasicDescription.Synopsis: With Sarah Montague and John Humphrys. Includes Sports Desk at 7.25am and 8.25am; Weather at 7.55am; Thought For The Day at 7.45am.

BasicDescription.Title: Home Truths
BasicDescription.Synopsis: John Peel takes another wry look at the foibles of family life .

BasicDescription.Title: Excess Baggage
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Arthur Smith opens his oddly shaped bags, full of the best travellers' tales, anecdotes and stories from around the globe.

BasicDescription.Title: British Manufacturing...
BasicDescription.Synopsis: ...And My Part In Its Downfall: John Fortune recalls the way work used to be. At the top of the pile, management-speak remains an arcane dialect incomprehensible to normal people.

BasicDescription.Title: The Week In Westminster
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Peter Oborne of the Spectator reports from behind the scenes at Westminster.

BasicDescription.Title: From Our Own Correspondent
BasicDescription.Synopsis: BBC Foreign correspondents report on international events and issues. Introduced by Kate Adie.

BasicDescription.Title: News
BasicDescription.Synopsis: The latest national and international news headlines from BBC Radio 4.

BasicDescription.Title: Money Box
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Paul Lewis brings you the latest news from the world of personal finance, and impartial money advice.

BasicDescription.Title: The News Quiz
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Simon Hoggart hosts the topical panel game. With Alan Coren, Jeremy Hardy, Linda Smith and Francis Wheen. .

BasicDescription.Title: News
BasicDescription.Synopsis: The latest national and international news from BBC Radio 4.

BasicDescription.Title: Any Answers?
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Jonathan Dimbleby takes listeners' calls in response to last night's edition of Any Questions? To air your views call 08700 010 0444 [national rates].

BasicDescription.Title: The Saturday Play
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Offside In Bohemia: By Melanie Garrett Fraser. Francis Novacek's job as a private detective takes him back to Prague, the mysterious home city of his exiled father.

Offside In Bohemia By Melanie Garrett Fraser
Francois Novacek, former investigative journalist for the French left-wing daily, Liberation, has packed in the news game to become a private detective. He is now heading for Prague, on the trail of a French novelist who has disappeared during a trip to a mystery-writing convention in the Czech Republic.
In this magical city where everything seems both strange and familiar, a fusion of the past and present, Novacek's investigation into recent Czech history and the methods of the recently defunct Writer's Union will ultimately lead him to confront the darker sides of his own past.
Novacek's father died when he was still a young boy. Novacek has always been proud of the fact that his father - a footballer at the top of his game - played for his country, but is troubled by his father's warning to him never to return to Prague. While visiting his father's old haunts, Novacek begins to uncover answers to worrying questions about his flight from Prague.
The only thing Novacek needs to remember is the Offside Rule: there is a penalty to pay for being in the wrong place at the wrong time.

BasicDescription.Title: Grapes of War
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Collaboration Or Resistance?: Andrew Jefford concludes a two-part series investigating how France's wine-makers coped with Nazi occupation.

Collaboration Or Resistance?
Andrew Jefford concludes a two-part series investigating how France's wine-makers coped with Nazi occupation.
As the Germans sent in the weinfï¿½hrers to negotiate the effective seizure of huge quantities of wine, a new level of cunning and counter-cunning set in - with the Germans determined to enjoy the fruits of their victory and the French equally eager to protect the very symbol of their culture and way of life.

BasicDescription.Title: Weekend Woman's Hour
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Highlights of the week's Woman's Hour programmes, presented by Martha Kearney.

BasicDescription.Title: Saturday PM
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Dan Damon presents full coverage and analysis of the day's news and the sports headlines.

BasicDescription.Title: Back Row
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Joe Cornish talks to writer Steven Knight about his new film Dirty Pretty Things, an expose of the lives of illegal immigrants and the conditions in which they are forced to work.

BasicDescription.Title: Shipping Forecast
BasicDescription.Synopsis: The latest Shipping Forecast and Weather.

BasicDescription.Title: Six O'Clock News
BasicDescription.Synopsis: The latest national and international news from BBC Radio 4.

BasicDescription.Title: Loose Ends
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Ned Sherrin talks to Peter Ustinov and his biographer John Miller. Also in the studio are Emma Freud and Richard Coles.

BasicDescription.Title: Saturday Review
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Tom Sutcliffe and friends look at Woody Allen's new film The Curse of the Jade Scorpion. Also under scrutiny is the Albrecht Durer exhibition at the British Museum.

BasicDescription.Title: Talking To Myself
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Series in which writers who have published memoirs compose and read a letter to themselves when young. Diana Athill looks back over six decades to write to her 23-year-old self.

BasicDescription.Title: The Archive Hour
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Live From The Grand Ole Opry: Hank Wangford tells the story of the longest running radio programme in the world - as American as apple pie and just as sweet.

Live From The Grand Ole Opry Hank Wangford tells the story of the longest running radio programme in the world. The Grand Ole Opry was largely responsible for making country music the multi billion dollar industry that it is today, and turning the polite, Southern town of Nashville into Music City.

BasicDescription.Title: Classic Serial
BasicDescription.Synopsis: To The Lighthouse: Virginia Woolf's moving portrait a family on holiday in Scotland before the First World War, dramatised for radio in two parts. With Vanessa Redgrave.

To The Lighthouse By Virginia Woolf, dramatised by Eileen Atkins
Episode One
The story of the Ramsay family holidaying in Scotland before the First World War is dominated by Virginia Woolf's wonderful portrait of the beautiful Mrs Ramsay. The family's planned expedition to a lighthouse nearby is a symbolic and emotional journey which 'moves most surely and with beauty among the deepest and most delicate motions of the human heart and spirit.'
Mrs Ramsay ...... Vanessa Redgrave Mr Ramsay ...... John Wood Lily Briscoe ...... Juliet Stevenson William Bankes ...... Edward Petherbridge Charles Tansley ...... Robert Glenister Minta ...... Jane Whittenshaw Cam ...... Alison Pettitt Mr Carmichael ...... Gavin Muir Paul ...... Tom George Nancy ...... Gemma Saunders Andrew ...... David Thorpe James ...... George Allonby

BasicDescription.Title: News
BasicDescription.Synopsis: The latest national and international news from BBC Radio 4.

BasicDescription.Title: Brain Of Britain 2002
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Robert Robinson chairs the nationwide general knowledge contest. The second semi-final is between contestants from the Midlands and north west of England.

Robert Robinson chairs the nationwide general knowledge contest. The second semi-final is between contestants from the Midlands and north west of England.
The contestants are:
Stephen Goddard - a Lecturer Honor Browning - a retired Director of Nurse Education Richard Towers - a Charity Director Don Young - a retired Teacher

BasicDescription.Title: Adventures In Poetry
BasicDescription.Synopsis: The Farmer's Bride by Charlotte Mew: Peggy Reynolds explores the lasting appeal of a poem first published in 1912 that has powerful echoes in the modern world.
